children: A 50-year-old woman experiences temperature-dependent episodic finger pain. She has no other medical problems.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is primary Raynaud phenomenon. The hands are the most likely sites for the attacks of vasospasm that characterize Raynaud phenomenon. A typical episode is precipitated by cold exposure, which is soon followed by distinctive color changes of white (ischemic phase) or blue (cyanotic phase). With rewarming, there is the onset of redness, which heralds reperfusion.
